citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
On 5/4/2024, a keeper noted that the adult, female raccoon named "Shortcake" was scratching and had about 1.5" of hair
loss on the tip of the tail. The scratching and hair loss were not reported to the attending veterinarian until 5/13/2024.
From the time the raccoon's condition was first noticed until the time the veterinarian was notified (nine days), the animal
was losing weight and the hair loss progressed to include the majority of the hindquarters, tail and left side of the animal.
Failure to promptly report health or behavioral issues to the attending veterinarian resulted in delayed veterinary
intervention that could have stopped the progression of the weight loss, hair loss and any discomfort the animal was
experiencing from itching. Daily observation of all animals to assess their health and well-being must be performed, and a
mechanism of direct and frequent communication is required so that timely and accurate information on problems of
animal health, behavior and well being is conveyed to the attending veterinarian.

An adult female Southern tamandua named "Morticia" was found deceased on the morning of 3/9/2024 in her outdoor
enclosure following exposure to low outdoor temperatures. The low temperature for that day in Clovis, NM was predicted
to be below freezing at 27 degrees Fahrenheit; National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) records
indicate the actual low temperature for that day in Clovis, NM was 19 degrees Fahrenheit. Despite the advance warning of
freezing temperatures, the zoo director stated that the animal keeper responsible for the tamandua failed to move the
animal to its indoor holding enclosure. The attending veterinarian mentioned the animal had recently recovered from a
serious illness and also had a history of declining in health status during times of colder temperatures. The necropsy
notes also state that the attending veterinarian discussed with the zoo director, the possibility that the cold environmental
temperature may be the cause of death, and the necropsy report shows there were no findings to suggest illness, trauma,
congenital defect, malnutrition or other chronic condition.
Southern tamanduas are not acclimated to cold or freezing conditions, which can lead to discomfort, illness or even death.
When climatic conditions present a threat to an animal's health or well-being, the facility must take appropriate measures
to alleviate the impact of those conditions; animals must never be subjected to any combination of temperature, humidity,
and time that is detrimental to the animal's health or well-being, taking into consideration such factors as the animal's age,
species, breed, overall health status, and acclimation.
TO BE CORRECTED FROM THE DATE OF THIS INSPECTION ON 05/23/2024 AND GOING FORWARD.

A primary enclosure housing one adult, male blue and gold macaw is rusted in several areas with which the animal can
make contact; droppings cover some of these porous, rusted areas.
Materials that cannot be completely cleaned and properly disinfected can harbor harmful microbes that could cause
animal illness. Surfaces of housing facilities must be constructed in a manner and made of materials that allow them to be
readily cleaned and/or sanitized, or removed and replaced when worn or soiled. Interior surfaces and surfaces that come
into contact with birds must be free of rust or damage that affects the structural integrity of the surface or prevents
cleaning.
TO BE CORRECTED BY JUNE 3, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the zoo director.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(3)  Critical Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
On 5/4/2024, a keeper noted that the adult, female raccoon named "Shortcake" was scratching and had about 1.5" of hair 
loss on the tip of the tail. The scratching and hair loss were not reported to the attending veterinarian until 5/13/2024.

intervention that could have stopped the progression of the weight loss, hair loss and any discomfort the animal was 
experiencing from itching. Daily observation of all animals to assess their health and well-being must be performed, and a 
mechanism of direct and frequent communication is required so that timely and accurate information on problems of 
animal health, behavior and well being is conveyed to the attending veterinarian. 
2.131(e)  Critical
   
Handling of animals. 
An adult female Southern tamandua named "Morticia" was found deceased on the morning of 3/9/2024 in her outdoor 
enclosure following exposure to low outdoor temperatures. The low temperature for that day in Clovis, NM was predicted 
to be below freezing at 27 degrees Fahrenheit; National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) records 
indicate the actual low temperature for that day in Clovis, NM was 19 degrees Fahrenheit. Despite the advance warning of 
freezing temperatures, the zoo director stated that the animal keeper responsible for the tamandua failed to move the 
animal to its indoor holding enclosure. The attending veterinarian mentioned the animal had recently recovered from a 
serious illness and also had a history of declining in health status during times of colder temperatures. The necropsy 
notes also state that the attending veterinarian discussed with the zoo director, the possibility that the cold environmental 
temperature may be the cause of death, and the necropsy report shows there were no findings to suggest illness, trauma, 
congenital defect, malnutrition or other chronic condition.  
Southern tamanduas are not acclimated to cold or freezing conditions, which can lead to discomfort, illness or even death. 
When climatic conditions present a threat to an animal's health or well-being, the facility must take appropriate measures 
to alleviate the impact of those conditions; animals must never be subjected to any combination of temperature, humidity, 
and time that is detrimental to the animal's health or well-being, taking into consideration such factors as the animal's age, 
species, breed, overall health status, and acclimation. 
TO BE CORRECTED FROM THE DATE OF THIS INSPECTION ON 05/23/2024 AND GOING FORWARD.

3.150(c)(2) 
   
Facilities, general. 
A primary enclosure housing one adult, male blue and gold macaw is rusted in several areas with which the animal can 
make contact; droppings cover some of these porous, rusted areas.  
Materials that cannot be completely cleaned and properly disinfected can harbor harmful microbes that could cause 
animal illness. Surfaces of housing facilities must be constructed in a manner and made of materials that allow them to be 
readily cleaned and/or sanitized, or removed and replaced when worn or soiled. Interior surfaces and surfaces that come 
into contact with birds must be free of rust or damage that affects the structural integrity of the surface or prevents 
cleaning. 
TO BE CORRECTED BY JUNE 3, 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the zoo director.
